raw_text:
What now for Kelly Holmes?
 
 Last April, Kelly Holmes spoke to the BBC Sport website about her loneliness, her fight to stay fit and her decision not to contest both the 800m and 1500m at the Olympics.
 
 It just goes to show even the most meticulous and measured athletes cannot predict what fate has in store for them. Four months later, Holmes stormed to double Olympic gold and has since been made a Dame, won the BBC Sport Personality of the Year and written a book whilst still finding time to coach aspiring athletes. With so much time spent in the spotlight, Holmes has increasingly dropped hints that her ambition on the track has begun to wilt. And when asked about her plans for both the indoor and outdoor seasons ahead, the 34-year-old has repeatedly chosen to tick the "don't know" box. Holmes has now pulled out of this weekend's European Indoor Championships, where she was selected for both the 800m and 1500m, because of a hamstring injury. But should we be surprised if the Olympic champion over both those distances decides she just does not feel like racing anymore? "Well, it's a lot easier being the double Olympic champion, being feted by everybody, than training to be at the top in middle distance running," points out former Olympian and BBC pundit Steve Cram. "You have to have a real strong desire to carry on doing it even if you're very talented."
 
 Holmes' drive and determination have always been unquestionable - that is the reason she has battled back from a string of injuries that threatened to see her finish her career empty-handed. But alarm bells start ringing when the Kent athlete begins questioning herself. "Will I have as much commitment, desire and energy to go through a major championship?" Holmes asked in the New Year. "That is what I don't know." At 34, Holmes will also be aware that time is running out. US 400m and 200m legend Michael Johnson, a five-time Olympic gold medallist, retired shortly after his 34th birthday as did Britain's double Olympic champion decathlete Daley Thompson. The physical demands of the day-to-day grind will only get harder for Holmes, who has already admitted she "doesn't like the training anymore." Whilst out on the circuit the allure of defeating a double Olympic champion will spur her opponents on. Holmes will not want to needlessly suffer the indignity of being beaten. Unless she is certain she has a strong chance of winning any race, she will not step onto the track. But if the Kent athlete finds the form that fuelled her ambitions last summer, there are more prizes up for grabs. The day after completing her double in Athens, the 34-year-old revealed she would still like to win her first indoors title.
 
 Holmes' wish could easily be met in Madrid before she goes on to prepare for the outdoor season where there are still scores to be settled, such as a first gold at the World Championships in Helsinki. There is just one small truth which could gnaw away at Holmes' motivation - the realisation that no matter how hard she trains, nothing she wins now can surpass her achievements in Athens. On the other hand, if those achievements cannot be matched shouldn't they be at least shared and celebrated? "You don't get the chance very often in your career to step onto the track as the double Olympic champion," agreed Cram. "You want to be able to take your bow in front of the fans because it's a fantastic feeling. "I think deep down Kelly wants to run. I think she will compete and run races on the circuits but whether or not she runs in the major championships is much less certain."
 
 Athletics fans had every reason to believe they would see the new-look Kelly Holmes tearing up the track again. After her Olympic glory she emphatically denied she planned to retire. So, why is Holmes dragging her heels about making a decision on where, when or whether to even bother competing again? "That's just Kelly," explains Cram. "She's always been like that. "She enjoys people trying to guess what she is going to do next. She knows every time she makes a pronouncement now it's headline news. "Kelly has to figure out for herself what it is she wants and that will be based on athletics decisions, whether she can be competitive, if she is fit enough to put her neck on the line. "And if she decides not to run again, no-one is going to turn round and say 'you're making the wrong decision.'"
llama3.2:1b:
Kelly Holmes has retired from track racing after a double Olympic gold at 34. She had planned to compete in several major championships but pulled out of the European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury. 

Holmes' drive and determination are questioned by some, with former Olympian Steve Cram saying it's "easier being the double Olympic champion" and that she needs to decide if she wants to continue competing based on her own decision-making.

At 34, Holmes will be aware of time running out as she approaches the end of her career. She has already retired from track and field twice before. 

Holmes' future plans are unclear, with some speculating about potential indoor titles or World Championships aspirations in the next few months.
llama3.2:3b: Kelly Holmes has withdrawn from the European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury, sparking concerns about her future in athletics. Former Olympic champion Steve Cram believes that Holmes' drive and determination may be waning, as she questions whether she can maintain her commitment and desire to compete at a high level. At 34, Holmes is aware that time is running out and the physical demands of training will only get harder. She has already admitted to not liking the training anymore and will likely only step onto the track if she feels she has a strong chance of winning.
gemma2:2b: Kelly Holmes recently achieved Olympic double gold but has expressed uncertainty about future competition. She pulled out of the European Indoor Championships due to injury and remains unsure about her participation in major events like the World Championships.  Experts believe time is a factor, as she is 34 and faces increasing physical demands. While many fans anticipate her return to track racing, Holmes' motivations are unclear and she may prioritize personal enjoyment over competition. Her indecisiveness stems from her preference for not making definitive decisions before fully analyzing her preparedness and potential for success.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Kelly Holmes has become a household name due to her Olympic gold medal in 800m and 1500m, yet she seems hesitant about starting training again. She will not wish to step off the track but is still determined to win all of them this season. Cram believes Holmes should focus on what makes her special, rather than her potential.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Kelly Holmes has retired from track running at age 34, having won two Olympic gold medals but struggles with motivation as she faces diminishing physical demands in her late career. Her decision to withdraw from European Indoor Championships raises questions about whether she still wants to compete and could lead to a loss of potential titles for the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.
qwen2.5:3b: What now for Kelly Holmes? Last April, Holmes spoke about her Olympics ambitions but by April, she had won double Olympic gold, been made a Dame, won BBC Sport Personality of the Year, written a book, and was coaching aspiring athletes. She has since dropped hints her track ambitions are waning. Currently, she has pulled out of this weekend’s European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury. At 34, Holmes is aware time is running out; former Olympic champions who were her contemporaries have retired. Former Olympian Steve Cram suggests the athlete needs strong desire and commitment to continue racing, unlike when she was feted by everyone post-Olympics. Holmes’ hesitation may stem from a lack of desire or energy for major championships, but she might still win indoors titles. While some argue she should compete for memories in her career, others believe she should retire gracefully if her achievements can't be matched. She enjoys the attention and keeps guessing about her next move.

The article highlights Holmes' personal reasons for choosing not to compete in these upcoming events, including her desire to race again and the need to train for indoor championships that may or may not be a better option. The AI assistant does not provide specific reasoning or insights from Holmes or other sources.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Kelly Holmes has been with us for quite some time now. She won a double Olympic gold, which many people consider one of the greatest achievements in the history of athletics. In her career, she has been unstoppable, dominating in both indoor and outdoor events. This season, she has been focusing on her comeback after a hiatus caused by injuries that put her on the verge of retirement. As Kelly Holmes looks to continue her winning ways, it is essential to understand her motivations and what drives her to compete at an elite level.

For the past four months, Holmes has been training tirelessly in preparation for her European Indoor Championships in Rotterdam. However, she has now decided not to participate in this event due to a lingering hip issue that has left her feeling overwhelmed with training. This decision may be taken as a reflection of the difficulty in maintaining peak fitness levels at an elite level.

Furthermore, Holmes' coaches and close friends have expressed concern over her motivation and dedication to continue competing at such high levels. They believe that her recent loss in the indoor 800m has had a negative impact on her confidence and overall well-being. The uncertainty of whether she can compete at the same level as before remains an open question for both fans and experts alike.

In summary, Kelly Holmes' decision not to participate in the European Indoor Championships may be influenced by various factors. It is essential to consider her health and long-term goals when evaluating her motivations and decisions. As she steps onto the track in Rotterdam, Holmes will be faced with a series of questions - should she risk injury or continue to chase victories? The outcome may have significant implications for her legacy and career path.
phi:2.7b: Kelly Holmes, who won double Olympic gold in Athens, is now 34 years old and may be questioning her desire to continue competing. She has already pulled out of the European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury. Even though she is still highly regarded as an athlete, she expresses concerns about losing commitment and energy for major championships. Additionally, her age will make it harder to maintain her level of physical demands. However, if she finds her form on the circuit and wins races, there are still more rewards up for grabs in other competitions. Ultimately, whether or not Kelly decides to compete again is uncertain, but the focus should be on celebrating her achievements as a double Olympic champion and allowing her to make that decision for herself.
orca-mini:3b: Kelly Holmes, a double Olympic champion in both the 800m and 1500m, has pulled out of this weekend's European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury. The 34-year-old athlete has been struggling with injuries lately and is unsure about her future plans for the sport. She has been a veteran athlete in the track and field community and has won many admirers with her determination and dedication. However, her recent decisions have been questionable, and fans are eager to see what she will do next.
hermes3:3b: Kelly Holmes's future uncertain; double Olympic champion questions commitment to track racing after success.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Kelly Holmes, the double Olympic champion, has dropped hints that her ambition on the track may have waned due to the ease of being a double champion. She questioned whether she will have the commitment, desire, and energy for a major championship and considered the possibility of retiring. Despite recent injuries and doubts about her future in middle-distance running, Holmes still hopes to win an indoor title and aims to compete in the upcoming outdoor season. Former BBC pundit Steve Cram believes that Holmes may decide to run again but ultimately understands her desire for privacy regarding her decisions.
stablelm2:1.6b: Kelly Holmes has struggled with loneliness and doubts about continuing to compete in middle-distance running, after winning double Olympic gold in 2004. However, despite a recent hamstring injury preventing her from competing at this weekend's European Indoor Championships, Holmes remains committed to athletics. She acknowledges the allure of defeating a double Olympic champion, but is cautious not to needlessly suffer defeat. Should she regain fitness and confidence, Holmes will aim for first-place finishes in indoor and outdoor events, including the World Championships in Helsinki. However, there are concerns about whether her achievements in Athens can be surpassed in future competitions. As a Dame and BBC Sport Personality of the Year recipient, Holmes enjoys fame but acknowledges that it's important to compete when able and understand the risks involved in pursuing athletics at an elite level.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Kelly Holmes, a 34-year-old double Olympic champion in the 800m and 1500m, has been ambitious but increasingly questioning her commitment to competitive running. Despite her remarkable achievements, including winning gold at both distances in Athens and becoming a Dame, she's facing a critical juncture. Holmes has pulled out of the European Indoor Championships due to a hamstring injury and has expressed doubts about competing in major championships further. Her decision-making process is influenced by her desire for public interest and media attention, rather than solely on athletic performance or potential wins.

Former Olympian Steve Cram notes that Holmes' drive to continue has been instrumental in overcoming past injuries, but the physical demands of training at 34 are intensifying. The pressure of maintaining her double Olympic title and avoiding defeats could also be factors in her hesitation. While she still harbors ambitions for indoor and outdoor titles, including a first indoors victory and a gold at the World Championships, Holmes must weigh these against the personal satisfaction of stepping onto the track as a double Olympic champion, an experience unparalleled in her career.

Cram believes deep down, Holmes wants to compete and run races on the circuit. Ultimately, her decisions will depend on whether she feels capable of being competitive and fitting into the major championship schedules without unnecessary risk of injury.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Kelly Holmes, after winning double Olympic gold, becoming a Dame, and achieving widespread recognition, is uncertain about her future in athletics. Despite her past determination and resilience, she has hinted at waning ambition and has withdrawn from the European Indoor Championships due to injury. At 34, she faces the physical challenges of maintaining top form and questions her commitment to future competitions. While she has expressed interest in winning an indoor title and competing in the World Championships, she acknowledges that nothing can surpass her Athens triumph. Former Olympian Steve Cram believes she still wants to compete but is unsure about major championships. Holmes has not confirmed her plans, enjoying the speculation around her next move, and will ultimately decide based on her competitiveness and fitness. If she retires, her legacy remains unquestioned.
